Did you know that today is Constitution Day?

Citizens of the United States have celebrated Independence Day and Presidents' Day since the 1870s, and in 2005, the nation began to celebrate Constitution Day. Also know as Citizenship Day, Constitution Day is an American holiday honoring the day 39 delegates to the Constitutional Convention signed the United States Constitution. This historic date was September 17, 1787.

Learn more at https://www.constitutionfacts.com/us-constitution-day/history-of-constitution-day/

Today marks the beginning of National Hispanic Heritage Month!

Each year, Americans observe National Hispanic Heritage Month from September 15 to October 15, by celebrating the histories, cultures and contributions of American citizens whose ancestors came from Spain, Mexico, the Caribbean and Central and South America.

Did you know that the U.S. Hispanic population reached 60.6 million in 2019, up from 50.7 million in 2010. This makes Hispanics the nation’s second-fastest-growing racial or ethnic group after Asian Americans. Hispanics made up 18% of the U.S. population in 2019, up from 16% in 2010 and just 5% in 1970 (source: Pew Research Center).

#HispanicHeritageMonth2020

Today we celebrate the anniversary of Juneteenth, a holiday that commemorates the last enslaved African Americans in the United States being declared free.

The Emancipation Proclamation was issued by President Abraham Lincoln on January 1, 1863, however, the news of freedom did not reach Texas until two and a half years later. It came by way of Major General Gordon Granger, who announced General Order No. 3 to the people of Galveston, Texas on June 19, 1865.

"Hold those things that tell your history and protect them. During slavery, who was able to read or write or keep anything? The ability to have somebody to tell your story to is so important. It says: 'I was here. I may be sold tomorrow. But you know I was here.'"- Maya Angelou, literary icon and activist

Check out the Juneteenth events happening locally: https://www.kitsapsun.com/story/news/2020/06/19/juneteenth-preview-events-happening-kitsap-weekend/3207272001/

What does "home-based learning" look like?

Mrs. Crisp’s class at Kitsap Lake Elementary has been doing a "Noon Zoom" meeting every weekday since school buildings closed. Mrs. Crisp tries to recreate the morning meeting they had every day in the classroom which includes a greeting (each week is a different language), a share, and then a fun activity. (3/18/2020) Some important clarification on our FREE Grab-n-Go lunch program:

**Students can get meals at ANY school in the District - not just their own school! We invite you to go to any location that is convenient for your family.

post_text:
We've heard about some confusion about the amount these replacement levies are going to cost homeowners.

Rates are per $1000 of assessed value.

Here is how to calculate the estimated impact on a home assessed at $200,000:

>>Current rate: $3.14 x 200 = $628 / 12 months = $52.33 per month

>>Proposed rate: $3.73 x 200 = $746 / 12 months = $62.16 per month

If the two replacement levies pass, the owner of a $200,000 home would see an estimated increase of $118 annually, or $9.83 per month.

This rate per thousand is actually LOWER than the local rate in 2017, before the state changed its funding mechanism for school operations and programming due to the "McCleary Decision."

It is important to remember these are estimates. Voters approve a collection amount and the actual rate per thousand is determined based on assessed values of homes in the area.

Learn more about our proposed levies at www.BremertonSchools.org/levy.

Please feel free to contact us at 360-473-1002 or Communications@BremertonSchools.org if you have questions!

We want to share some information about situation that occurred this morning while Bus L was en route to Bremerton High School.

Around 7:00 a.m., a bicyclist reported that a bus made contact with her bike while the bus was traveling at very low speed, turning from 13th Street onto Lincoln Avenue.

Our transportation dispatcher contacted 9-1-1. The State Patrol and Bremerton Police Department responded. They found no evidence that contact was made with the bus. The bicyclist did not report any injuries. No citation was written.

One student reported hitting her head on the seat in front of her when the bus stopped. She was given an ice pack and her parent/guardian is being contacted.

We will be notifying parents of students assigned to Bus L this afternoon - after school is out so we aren't interrupting parents' work days with a non-emergency "robo-call." But we wanted to post this information publicly as we realize people may have driven by the scene and are wondering what happened.

Marco Dicicco
Transportation Director
Bremerton School District

Gratitude tips #6 and #7 from the Child Mind Institute:

6. Put things in perspective. Talk to your kids about those who are less fortunate. Don’t scare them, but don’t keep them in the dark either. Understanding that not everyone has the same advantages will help them develop compassion for others and gratitude for their own privileges.

7. Let kids choose. Encourage kids to turn their interests into action. Whether it’s a fundraising drive at school, a bake sale, or a run for charity, expressing her interests and using her skills for a good cause is a great way to boost her confidence and give her a chance to give back at the same time.

https://childmind.org/article/10-tips-raising-grateful-kids/

Tip #3 from the Child Mind Institute as we continue our month-long focus on gratitude.

Have a talk. For some kids, especially young children or those who have trouble understanding emotions, it can help to have a talk about how showing appreciation makes other people feel. Try asking your child how he feels when people say thank you to him for doing something nice, and then how he feels when they don’t. Going over his own feelings will help him understand how his behavior affects others and make it easier for him to understand the emotional benefits of being grateful.

https://childmind.org/article/10-tips-raising-grateful-kids/

Point out generosity. Call attention to it when people (including your kids!) do things that go beyond what’s expected — helping without being asked, being especially thoughtful, or taking extra time to do something because it’s important to someone else. Send the message that you will notice if they knock themselves out for you, or for someone else.

Point out generosity. Call attention to it when people (including your kids!) do things that go beyond what’s expected — helping without being asked, being especially thoughtful, or taking extra time to do something because it’s important to someone else. Send the message that you will notice if they knock themselves out for you, or for someone else.

Our November "character trait of the month" is gratitude! Throughout the month, we'll be sharing 10 tips from the Child Mind Institute on how to raise a grateful child.

Here is tip #1: Set an example. Kids learn a lot from watching their parents. Show them what it means to be grateful by offering a genuine “thank you!” to a waitress who serves your food, a helpful neighbor, someone who holds the door open for you. But don’t stop there — include your kids, too. Thanking children for doing things that are helpful, even when they are chores like putting away toys, reinforces the behavior and lets them know they’re appreciated.

You can find the complete article at: https://childmind.org/article/10-tips-raising-grateful-kids/
